image.altText: A man looks at stock prices through the window of the ASX in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market rises to its highest level in a month, while ASIC cancels the financial services licence of cryptocurrency firm FTX's local subsidiary. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises to four-week high, ASIC cancels crypto firm FTX's financial services licence

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has risen to its highest level in four weeks, and managed to snap a two-day losing streak. Strong gains in mining and energy stocks helped to lift the ASX 200 index up 0.6%, to close at 7,324 points. The miners rose after iron ore prices closed higher overnight, boosted by heightened expectations of more supportive measures from China following weaker-than-expected economic data. Rio Tinto fell 0.7%, after the mining giant flagged concerns about a global economic slowdown, and reported its second-quarter iron ore shipments missed analysts' estimates, BHP and Fortescue Metals fell 0.3% and 1.9% respectively. Woodside Energy climbed 1.4% even after reporting its second-quarter revenue missed estimates due to weaker liquefied natural gas prices and maintenance work at some of its facilities in Western Australia. Fuel retailer Ampol gained 4.4% after revealing its Lytton refinery margin for June improved to $US12.69 per barrel, reflecting improved production mix as the refinery returned to normal operations by the end of May as planned. BrainChip Holdings surged 6.8% to mark its best day in six weeks after the advanced AI chipmaker received a patent grant in the United States on one of its neuromorphic processors. Neuromorphic processors mimic the way the brain works and allow devices to use signals from physical neurons to carry out computations. On the flip side, Northern Star Resources plunged 5.8% after unveiling its full-year production forecast (which fell short of market expectations).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes at four-week high, boosted by mining and energy stocks

children.content: The local share market has risen to its highest level in four weeks, and managed to snap a two-day losing streak.
Strong gains in mining and energy stocks helped to lift the ASX 200 index up 0.6%, to close at 7,324 points.
The miners rose after iron ore prices closed higher overnight, boosted by heightened expectations of more supportive measures from China following weaker-than-expected economic data.
Rio Tinto fell 0.7%, after the mining giant flagged concerns about a global economic slowdown, and reported its second-quarter iron ore shipments missed analysts' estimates,
BHP and Fortescue Metals fell 0.3% and 1.9% respectively.

Woodside Energy climbed 1.4% even after reporting its second-quarter revenue missed estimates due to weaker liquefied natural gas prices and maintenance work at some of its facilities in Western Australia.

Fuel retailer Ampol gained 4.4% after revealing its Lytton refinery margin for June improved to $US12.69 per barrel, reflecting improved production mix as the refinery returned to normal operations by the end of May as planned.
BrainChip Holdings surged 6.8% to mark its best day in six weeks after the advanced AI chipmaker received a patent grant in the United States on one of its neuromorphic processors.
Neuromorphic processors mimic the way the brain works and allow devices to use signals from physical neurons to carry out computations.
On the flip side, Northern Star Resources plunged 5.8% after unveiling its full-year production forecast (which fell short of market expectations).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Kingdom is the latest country to report its consumer inflation figures, and they came in lower-than-expected. British inflation fell to 7.9% in the year to June (an improvement over last month's 8.7%). Reuters-polled economists were expecting a 8.2% annual rise in the headline consumer price index (CPI). Regardless, inflation remains too high in the UK and is well above the Bank of England’s 2% target. On a monthly basis, headline CPI increased by 0.1% over the previous month (lower than the 0.4% that economists were predicting). The biggest contributor to Britain's slowing inflation was the falling price of petrol, the Office for National Statistics said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UK inflation falls to lower-than-expected 7.9%

children.content: The United Kingdom is the latest country to report its consumer inflation figures, and they came in lower-than-expected.
British inflation fell to 7.9%
in the year to June (an improvement over last month's 8.7%).
Reuters-polled economists were expecting a 8.2% annual rise in the headline consumer price index (CPI).
Regardless, inflation remains too high in the UK and is well above the Bank of England’s 2% target.
On a monthly basis, headline CPI increased by 0.1% over the previous month (lower than the 0.4% that economists were predicting).
The biggest contributor to Britain's slowing inflation was the falling price of petrol, the Office for National Statistics said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific were mixed on Wednesday, with growth concerns dragging on China's market, while shares rose in Japan and Australia after healthy US company earnings and retail data bolstered hopes the world's biggest economy could avoid a recession. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.2%, and has been falling daily since China's weak economic growth data on Monday underscored the country's faltering pandemic recovery. Japan's Nikkei rose 0.9% and touched a two-week peak. Headline US retail sales data came in below forecasts, but core sales which exclude food, fuel and building materials, rose a solid 0.6% in June and had economists lifting gross domestic product (GDP) forecasts. Major US bank shares rose sharply on strong results, which drove Wall Street's industrial index, the Dow Jones, up 1.1% Shares of Microsoft surged 4%, adding $US100 billion in market value, after the company announced charges for artificial intelligence features in office software, a big first step in monetising AI's potential. Meanwhile, New Zealand inflation came in at 6% year-on-year (slower than a reading of 6.7% a month earlier), but above the market's expectations. Investors are now expecting NZ rates to stay higher for longer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mixed performance across global markets

children.content: Stock markets in the Asia-Pacific were mixed on Wednesday, with growth concerns dragging on China's market, while shares rose in Japan and Australia after healthy US company earnings and retail data bolstered hopes the world's biggest economy could avoid a recession.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell 1.2%, and has been falling daily since China's weak economic growth data on Monday underscored the country's faltering pandemic recovery.
Japan's Nikkei rose 0.9% and touched a two-week peak.

Headline US retail sales data came in below forecasts, but core sales which exclude food, fuel and building materials, rose a solid 0.6% in June and had economists lifting gross domestic product (GDP) forecasts.
Major US bank shares rose sharply on strong results, which drove Wall Street's industrial index, the Dow Jones, up 1.1%

Shares of Microsoft surged 4%, adding $US100 billion in market value, after the company announced charges for artificial intelligence features in office software, a big first step in monetising AI's potential.

Meanwhile, New Zealand inflation came in at 6% year-on-year (slower than a reading of 6.7% a month earlier), but above the market's expectations. Investors are now expecting NZ rates to stay higher for longer.
